result.execSummary:
The defendant Jeffrey T. Foley was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case. One or more other charges in this case were dismissed. The dismissed charges were not proven and have no legal effect. Jeffrey T. Foley is presumed innocent of the dismissed charges.

  • Jeffrey T. Foley was found guilty of Criminal Damage to Property, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 943.01(1).
  • Jeffrey T. Foley was found guilty of Intentional Timber Theft <=$2,500, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 26.05(2).
  • Jeffrey T. Foley was found guilty of Harvest without Notification [Modifiers: Repeater]. This is not a criminal offense and results only in a money penalty for this offense.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

records.addlTxt:
Case called at 10:28 a.m.
State appears by D.A. Gill. 
Victim Mark Kieler appears in the courtroom. 
No other appearances. 
State gives status of matter. 
State request Body Only Warrant. 
Court Orders Warrant and stay it for 48 hours.
Probation review hearing on December 10, 2018 at 10:00 am.
to Judge Jorgenson from DOC Agent Ashley Dickman
to Judge Jorgenson from Mark Kieler

Defendant Jeffrey T. Foley in court with attorney Timothy Luke Angel.  Jenna L Gill appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Other appearances:  Mark Kieler, Kenneth Kieler

Atty Angel informs Court that the parties have reached a plea agreement wherein defendant will enter pleas to Counts 1, 2 and 5 of the amended information.
D.A. Gill informs Court that victim notification was made.
Defendant enters plea of "no contest" to Counts 1, 2 and 5.
Court questions defendant re: his plea and waiver of rights.
Court questions defendant re: proposed plea agreement.
Parties stipulate to factual basis set out in criminal complaint.
Court also questions Atty Angel re: his client's plea and waiver of rights.
Court finds plea and waiver of rights is made freely, knowingly and voluntarily.  Court accepts plea and finds defendant guilty of Counts 1, 2 and 5.
State moves to dismiss Counts 3 and 4.  So ordered by the Court.
Mark Kieler (victim) makes statement to the Court.
D.A. Gill moves Court to adopt the plea agreement and gives argument in support of sentence proposed in the agreement.
Atty Angel gives argument re: sentence.
Further comments by D.A. Gill.  (Count 1 is a forfeiture and can't have a probation sentence.)
Defendant addresses the Court.
Court orders sentence as follows:
Count 1 - 30 days jail with Huber privileges commencing 12/1/17 at or before 6:00 p.m.
Count 2 & 5 - Sentence withheld, placed on probation for 3 years
Conditions:  
Restitution to Mark Kieler in the amount of $6,930.00  ($2,310 due by 11/9/18 and each year thereafter).  If defendant can't pay the total amount during his term of probation, he may request a hearing before the Court re: his ability to pay.
Restitution to Dean Paulson (TBD by DOC) within 60 days
Costs
Comply with all rules of probation
No contact with Mark Kieler, Dean Paulson and Kenneth Kieler

Atty. Angel informs court of status.  The parties have learned that the logging skid belongs to Mr. Foley's son.
D.A. Gill concurs.  The State has filed a brief addressing the release/return of the property to Mr. Foley and/or his son.

Jeffrey T. Foley's Affidavit in Support of Motion For Return of Logging Skid
State's Memorandum in opposition to Defendant's motion for return of logging skid
Motion hearing on May 8, 2017 at 01:30 pm.

Case called at 10:35 AM.  Defendant Jeffrey T. Foley in court with attorney Timothy Luke Angel.   Jenna Gill appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Attorney Angel informs the Court this Motion is regarding the return of a logging skid.  DNR had previously seized logging skid for evidence.  State does not dispute that logging skid was seized, but should not be released to Defendant based on fact it could be damaged and would not be able to be used as evidence at the time of the trial.  Restitution will exceed $10,000.00-2 separate victims.  Attorney Angel argues this piece of equipment is too large to be used (brought into the courtroom).  Court questions District Attorney Gill regarding evidentiary aspect of skid loader.  Court will reserve on this motion.  Court is reluctant to rule on this due to fact District Attorney will use the logging skid as evidence.  Court will request the parties, through affidavit, show ownership of logging skid, and where the logging skid is located at this time.  Motion hearing scheduled for May 8, 2017 at 01:30 pm.
Motion hearing on April 7, 2017 at 10:30 am.

Attorney Angel informs the Court Motion for return of logging skid filed, investigator hired, and is still ongoing.  State opposing motion.  Motion hearing scheduled for April 7, 2017 at 10:30 am.
